H0.text: Magma is the rock formed when dried lava from an old volcano is worn down, broken into small pieces, and those pieces pile up and are cemented together.

H1.text: Igneous is the classification of the new rock that forms when dried lava from an old volcano is worn down, broken into small pieces, piled up, and cemented together over time.

H2.text: Sedimentary is the classification of the new rock that forms when dried lava from an old volcano is worn down, broken into small pieces, piled up, and cemented together over time.

H3.text: Metamorphic is the classification of the new rock formed when dried lava from an old volcano is worn down and broken into small pieces, which then pile up and are cemented together.

A4.text: Lava, the name of magma when it emerges and flows over the surface

A5.text: Tuff is the lithified form of volcanic ash.

A6.text: Other sedimentary rocks: volcanic tuff and volcanic breccias formed by deposition and later cementation of lava fragments erupted by volcanoes.

A7.text: Lithification is the process in which sediments compact under pressure, expel connate fluids, and gradually become solid rock.

A8.text: Petrifaction, though often used as a synonym, is more specifically used to describe the replacement of organic material by silica in the formation of fossils.

A9.text: Concretion – In geology, a type of compact mass.

A10.text: Diagenesis – Physico-chemical changes in sediments occurring after their deposition.
